trans-unit.source: The CREATE ROLE statement allows you to create an SQL role.

seg-source.mrk: The CREATE ROLE statement allows you to create an SQL role.

target.mrk: The CREATE ROLE statement allows you to create an SQL role.

trans-unit.source: Only the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref> can create a role.

seg-source.mrk: Only the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref> can create a role.

target.mrk: Only the <xref href="rrefattrib26867.dita#rrefattrib26867">database owner</xref> can create a role.

trans-unit.source: For more information on roles, see "Using SQL roles" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: For more information on roles, see "Using SQL roles" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

target.mrk: For more information on roles, see "Using SQL roles" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: Syntax

seg-source.mrk: Syntax

target.mrk: Syntax

trans-unit.source: CREATE ROLE roleName

seg-source.mrk: CREATE ROLE roleName

target.mrk: CREATE ROLE roleName

trans-unit.source: Before you issue a CREATE ROLE statement, verify that the derby.database.sqlAuthorization property is set to TRUE. The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL authorization mode.

seg-source.mrk: Before you issue a CREATE ROLE statement, verify that the derby.database.sqlAuthorization property is set to TRUE.
The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL authorization mode.

target.mrk: Before you issue a CREATE ROLE statement, verify that the derby.database.sqlAuthorization property is set to TRUE.
The derby.database.sqlAuthorization property enables SQL authorization mode.

trans-unit.source: You cannot create a role name if there is a user by that name. An attempt to create a role name that conflicts with an existing user name raises the SQLException X0Y68.

seg-source.mrk: You cannot create a role name if there is a user by that name.
An attempt to create a role name that conflicts with an existing user name raises the SQLException X0Y68.

target.mrk: You cannot create a role name if there is a user by that name.
An attempt to create a role name that conflicts with an existing user name raises the SQLException X0Y68.

trans-unit.source: If user names are not controlled by the database owner (or administrator), it may be a good idea to use a naming convention for roles to reduce the possibility of collision with user names.

seg-source.mrk: If user names are not controlled by the database owner (or administrator), it may be a good idea to use a naming convention for roles to reduce the possibility of collision with user names.

target.mrk: If user names are not controlled by the database owner (or administrator), it may be a good idea to use a naming convention for roles to reduce the possibility of collision with user names.

trans-unit.source: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tries to avoid name collision between user names and role names, but this is not always possible, because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> has a pluggable authorization architecture. For example, an externally defined user may exist who has never yet connected to the database, created any schema objects, or been granted any privileges. If <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> knows about a user name, it will forbid creating a role with that name. Correspondingly, a user who has the same name as a role will not be allowed to connect. <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> built-in users are checked for collision when a role is created.

seg-source.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tries to avoid name collision between user names and role names, but this is not always possible, because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> has a pluggable authorization architecture.
For example, an externally defined user may exist who has never yet connected to the database, created any schema objects, or been granted any privileges.
If <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> knows about a user name, it will forbid creating a role with that name.
Correspondingly, a user who has the same name as a role will not be allowed to connect.
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> built-in users are checked for collision when a role is created.

target.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> tries to avoid name collision between user names and role names, but this is not always possible, because <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> has a pluggable authorization architecture.
For example, an externally defined user may exist who has never yet connected to the database, created any schema objects, or been granted any privileges.
If <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> knows about a user name, it will forbid creating a role with that name.
Correspondingly, a user who has the same name as a role will not be allowed to connect.
<ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> built-in users are checked for collision when a role is created.

trans-unit.source: A role name cannot start with the prefix SYS (after case normalization). The purpose of this restriction is to reserve a name space for system-defined roles at a later point. Use of the prefix SYS raises the SQLException 4293A.

seg-source.mrk: A role name cannot start with the prefix SYS (after case normalization).
The purpose of this restriction is to reserve a name space for system-defined roles at a later point.
Use of the prefix SYS raises the SQLException 4293A.

target.mrk: A role name cannot start with the prefix SYS (after case normalization).
The purpose of this restriction is to reserve a name space for system-defined roles at a later point.
Use of the prefix SYS raises the SQLException 4293A.

trans-unit.source: You cannot create a role with the name PUBLIC (after case normalization). PUBLIC is a reserved authorization identifier. An attempt to create a role with the name PUBLIC raises SQLException 4251B.

seg-source.mrk: You cannot create a role with the name <codeph>PUBLIC</codeph> (after case normalization).
<codeph>PUBLIC</codeph> is a reserved authorization identifier.
An attempt to create a role with the name PUBLIC raises SQLException 4251B.

target.mrk: You cannot create a role with the name <codeph>PUBLIC</codeph> (after case normalization).
<codeph>PUBLIC</codeph> is a reserved authorization identifier.
An attempt to create a role with the name PUBLIC raises SQLException 4251B.

target.mrk: Example of creating a role

trans-unit.source: CREATE ROLE purchases_reader;

target.mrk: CREATE ROLE purchases_reader;

trans-unit.source: CREATE ROLE public; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE "PUBLIC"; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE sysrole; -- throws SQLException;

seg-source.mrk: CREATE ROLE public; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE "PUBLIC"; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE sysrole; -- throws SQLException;

target.mrk: CREATE ROLE public; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE "PUBLIC"; -- throws SQLException; CREATE ROLE sysrole; -- throws SQLException;

trans-unit.source: Example of creating a role using a naming convention

seg-source.mrk: Example of creating a role using a naming convention

target.mrk: Example of creating a role using a naming convention

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the convention of giving every role name the suffix <codeph>_role</codeph>.

seg-source.mrk: The following example uses the convention of giving every role name the suffix <codeph>_role</codeph>.

target.mrk: The following example uses the convention of giving every role name the suffix <codeph>_role</codeph>.

trans-unit.source: CREATE ROLE purchases_reader_role;

seg-source.mrk: CREATE ROLE purchases_reader_role;

target.mrk: CREATE ROLE purchases_reader_role;
